tidyindex 0.0.1
  • Reference

Variable transformation

Source: R/pipeline-var-trans.R
var_trans.Rd

Specify either as an expression (like mutate) or using .method.

Usage

var_trans(data, ..., .method = NULL, .vars = NULL, .new_name = NULL)

Arguments

data

an index table object

...

expression

.method

the method use

.vars

variables

.new_name

the new name

Value

an index table

Details

When using .method, specifies the varaibles it applies to (`.vars`), can be multiple, use tidyselect syntax additional parameters will be parsed from `...` `.new_names` needs to be of same length as `.vars`

Examples


dt <- hdi %>% init(id = country, indicators = life_exp:gni_pc)
# single variable:
dt %>% var_trans(life_exp = rescale_minmax(life_exp))
#> Index pipeline: 
#> 
#> Summary: 
#> rescaling: `rescale_minmax(life_exp)` -> life_exp
#> 
#> Data: 
#> # A tibble: 191 × 9
#>       id country                  hdi life_…¹ exp_sch avg_sch gni_pc  diff  rank
#>    <dbl> <chr>                  <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1     1 Switzerland            0.962   0.955    16.5    13.9 66933.     5     3
#>  2     2 Norway                 0.961   0.932    18.2    13.0 64660.     6     1
#>  3     3 Iceland                0.959   0.915    19.2    13.8 55782.    11     2
#>  4     4 Hong Kong, China (SAR) 0.952   1        17.3    12.2 62607.     6     4
#>  5     5 Australia              0.951   0.971    21.1    12.7 49238.    18     5
#>  6     6 Denmark                0.948   0.876    18.7    13.0 60365.     6     5
#>  7     7 Sweden                 0.947   0.924    19.4    12.6 54489.     9     9
#>  8     8 Ireland                0.945   0.895    18.9    11.6 76169.    -3     8
#>  9     9 Germany                0.942   0.853    17.0    14.1 54534.     6     7
#> 10    10 Netherlands            0.941   0.885    18.7    12.6 55979.     3    10
#> # … with 181 more rows, and abbreviated variable name ¹​life_exp
dt %>% var_trans(.method = rescale_minmax, .vars = life_exp, min = 20, max = 85)
#> Index pipeline: 
#> 
#> Summary: 
#> rescaling: `rescale_minmax(var = life_exp, min = 20, max = 85)` -> life_exp
#> 
#> Data: 
#> # A tibble: 191 × 9
#>       id country                  hdi life_…¹ exp_sch avg_sch gni_pc  diff  rank
#>    <dbl> <chr>                  <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1     1 Switzerland            0.962   0.984    16.5    13.9 66933.     5     3
#>  2     2 Norway                 0.961   0.973    18.2    13.0 64660.     6     1
#>  3     3 Iceland                0.959   0.964    19.2    13.8 55782.    11     2
#>  4     4 Hong Kong, China (SAR) 0.952   1        17.3    12.2 62607.     6     4
#>  5     5 Australia              0.951   0.993    21.1    12.7 49238.    18     5
#>  6     6 Denmark                0.948   0.944    18.7    13.0 60365.     6     5
#>  7     7 Sweden                 0.947   0.969    19.4    12.6 54489.     9     9
#>  8     8 Ireland                0.945   0.954    18.9    11.6 76169.    -3     8
#>  9     9 Germany                0.942   0.933    17.0    14.1 54534.     6     7
#> 10    10 Netherlands            0.941   0.949    18.7    12.6 55979.     3    10
#> # … with 181 more rows, and abbreviated variable name ¹​life_exp
dt %>% var_trans(.method = rescale_minmax, .vars = life_exp, .new_name = "life_exp2")

#> 
#> Summary: 
#> rescaling: `rescale_minmax(var = life_exp)` -> life_exp2

# use tidyselect to apply the .method to multiple variables
dt %>% var_trans(.method = rescale_minmax, .vars = life_exp:exp_sch)
#> Index pipeline: 
#> 
#> Summary: 
#> rescaling: `rescale_minmax(var = life_exp)` -> life_exp
#> rescaling: `rescale_minmax(var = exp_sch)` -> exp_sch
#> 
#> Data: 
#> # A tibble: 191 × 9
#>       id country                  hdi life_…¹ exp_sch avg_sch gni_pc  diff  rank
#>    <dbl> <chr>                  <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1     1 Switzerland            0.962   0.955   0.706    13.9 66933.     5     3
#>  2     2 Norway                 0.961   0.932   0.815    13.0 64660.     6     1
#>  3     3 Iceland                0.959   0.915   0.878    13.8 55782.    11     2
#>  4     4 Hong Kong, China (SAR) 0.952   1       0.757    12.2 62607.     6     4
#>  5     5 Australia              0.951   0.971   1        12.7 49238.    18     5
#>  6     6 Denmark                0.948   0.876   0.849    13.0 60365.     6     5
#>  7     7 Sweden                 0.947   0.924   0.895    12.6 54489.     9     9
#>  8     8 Ireland                0.945   0.895   0.864    11.6 76169.    -3     8
#>  9     9 Germany                0.942   0.853   0.739    14.1 54534.     6     7
#> 10    10 Netherlands            0.941   0.885   0.848    12.6 55979.     3    10
#> # … with 181 more rows, and abbreviated variable name ¹​life_exp
# can also supply additional parameters
dt %>% var_trans(.method = rescale_minmax,
                 .vars = life_exp:exp_sch,
                 min = c(20, 0), max = c(85, 18),
                 .new_name = c("life_exp2", "exp_sch"))
#> Index pipeline: 
#> 
#> Summary: 
#> rescaling: `rescale_minmax(var = life_exp, min = 20, max = 85)` -> life_exp2
#> rescaling: `rescale_minmax(var = exp_sch, min = 0, max = 18)` -> exp_sch
#> 
#> Data: 
#> # A tibble: 191 × 10
#>       id country          hdi life_…¹ exp_sch avg_sch gni_pc  diff  rank life_…²
#>    <dbl> <chr>          <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
